metadata.title: My favorite (free) interactive data visualisation tools | by Charlotte Weil | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: My favorite (free) interactive data visualisation tools
metadata.description: Interactive web viewers are an important part of my work as a data scientist at Stanford University, supporting decision-makers to make targeted spatial planning choices for people and nature. When…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: supporting decision-makers to make targeted spatial planning choices for people and nature
visualize fine resolution maps across scales
the construction of a new road
my fantastic hack to building and serving home-made tilesets

all_paragraphs: Interactive web viewers are an important part of my work as a data scientist at Stanford University, supporting decision-makers to make targeted spatial planning choices for people and nature. When teaching, I get asked a lot about underlying tools, so here’s a quick take on the matter.

In the data era, where we suffer infobesity (information overload), making sense of lots of data efficiently has become an important skill; as a consequence, data visualisation has boomed. Indeed, data viz has become essential to explore large multidimensional datasets. Interactive data viz is particularly helpful to link different views of the data, filter through big datasets, or visualize fine resolution maps across scales…

In my work on ecosystem management, I’ve seen how communicating complex quantitative results to decision-makers in a user-friendly format is key to the success of a project. Interactive viewers facilitate discussions and tend to engage users easily, letting them investigate the datasets intuitively. In addition to their attractivity potential, they are really helpful to gain insights from complex datasets, research shows.

Famous global viewers monitor deforestation, coral reefs health, climate resilience, food systems, resources, sea level rise (…), and most recently coronavirus cases. These often even serve as databases for their topic, gathering up-to-date datasets. At a smaller scale, project-specific viewers serve a specific goal and intended audience, allowing collaborators to share and visualize data, fostering discussion across groups as teams iterate. For example, in the context of spatial development plans, viewers help partners investigate scenarios of developments, such as impact of the construction of a new road or of new protected areas…

So, what’s the best data visualization tool? There’s no one size-fits-all magic solution; like any good visual, the right tool depends on your audience, data formats and the key message to convey. Below, I’ll list the tools that I enjoy using, and link some examples.

Let’s start with the most powerful interactive plotting library: D3.js is the beast of interactive data visualisation. From the very simple interactive charts easily made with C3.js, to the most badass psychedelic, artistic, and insightful visuals. It cover almost all types of plots, from chord charts to word trees. D3.js is not easy, but there are plenty of tutorials and examples to support.

When it come to spatial data, Leaflet is the queen library for interactive mapping. Its power relies on its plug-ins, contributed by the community, which adapts to the trendiest data types. I use these for, in particular the one for shapefiles, geoJSONs, and most recently, found this one for (relatively small) rasters. For bigger rasters (and fastest display), I recommend using tiles. Commercial solutions (like Mapbox, ArcGIS Online or Carto) let you make and host tiles easily, but have data hosting limitations, and are never 100% customizable. I prefer to create my own tilesets, and it’s not as complicated as it seems (3 GDAL commands and then serve them smoothly with GitHub pages) > see my fantastic hack to building and serving home-made tilesets!

Now, for satellite imagery, Google Earth Engine (GEE) is probably your best bet. Pros: if you’re displaying datasets hosted by GEE (and they host many!), you’ll save considerable time. You also don’t need to worry about hosting or serving your viewer, as it’s hosted and served through GEE Apps. Cons: While the coding is simplified (thanks Google), it’s sandboxed so you don’t have full control to create the pretty interface you’re dreaming of. Also, app deployment is still in beta version. And it’s not open-source of course.

GitHub Pages makes it fantastically easy to deploy your own viewer (Settings > Options > GitHub Pages > Source > choose your branch and viewer folder). Your viewer’s URL looks like {your-username}.github.io/{repository-name}, but is customizable if you own a cooler domain.

Only need a fast prototype? If you don’t need to deploy a whole web-viewer, you can save a considerable amount of time (basically skip all the web development: no HTML nor CSS, jump straight to the JavaScript you need for your viz), by using Observable’s interactive JavaScript notebooks, usable online by loading your data.

Allergic to JavaScript? Worry no more. Some great Python librairies (Bokeh, Altair) let you to play around interactively (in Jupyter notebooks). Though Javascript remains the reference for anything that will be shared on the web, most of the js librairies mentioned above also have a python version (e.g Folium integrates Leaflet.js for Python data).
It’s always a trade-off between customizability and ease of implementation.

Commercial solutions exist (ArcGIS Storymaps allows easy creation of interactive stories combining medias, text, maps and charts; Tableau lets you create dashboards easily…), though they are inherently limited in terms of functionalities and customizability. Most function on a Freemium model. I honestly don’t know them well enough to provide good recommendations.
If you aren’t afraid of looking at code, and you know enough github to get your way around, try this:

Getting a hold of these visualization libraries, and getting everything to work together smoothly — from data formatting to deploying a viewer online — can be time consuming. To simplify this process, the wonderful Anna Häägg and I made a template for our colleagues to build web viewers for free, really quickly. It’s all open source, so it’s yours too!
It’s still quite new, so your feedback would be very welcome — take a look the demo, and clone the repo to get started.

Bottomline: as illustrated in this article, there are a plenty new libraries and tools to make ever fancier, prettier, colorful webmaps… I recommend to stay focused on the key message(s) to convey and the audience when picking a tool and designing a solution — sometimes the simplest is the most effective!
Keep in mind graphical integrity principles, and have fun!
● Genuine Earthling ■ Environmental Engineer ■ Data Scientist ■ Visual Thinker ▲ Ecosystems Modeling▲ Fast Prototyping ▲ Open Mind ●
